questionListItems.title: I travelled on the same distance and same route on two different buses and the fares were different.  Why?

answer.body:
It may be that the bus service with the higher fare is an Express Bus Service.

Express bus services are designed to provide faster connections by travelling via expressways. They also do not stop along certain sectors for faster point-to-point travel. As such, the fares of express bus services are differentiated from basic bus services. They follow a different fare structure and are higher. These includes the fares for local areas along their routes as these sectors are the boarding and alighting points for commuters of express bus services.

The point-to-point nature of express bus services, providing convenience and faster connections, is targeted at commuters who travel over long distances, e.g. from HDB towns to the city centre, and especially during peak hours. Commuters who wish to take express bus services for convenience and faster connections thus need to pay the higher fares as compared to basic bus services. These bus services can be identified via the Bus Service Information Posters displayed at en route bus stops.

questionListItems.title: I waited 15 minutes for the train this morning and the train was so packed that I had to take the next one. Can the PTC increase train frequencies to cater to the demand?

answer.body: All train services are regulated and licensed by the LTA. Matters pertaining to train services may be directed to the LTA or the relevant train operator.

topics.title: Matters Commonly Misdirected to the PTC

questionListItems.title: I waited for more than 20 minutes for the bus and when questioned the bus driver gave me a very rude reply. The bus was also old and dirty and the air con was not working properly. What is the PTC going to do about this?

answer.body: Bus operators are directly responsible for the satisfactory delivery of public transport service to their customers. Day-to-day operational matters such as bus scheduling and deployment, long waiting time, bus crowding, air-conditioning, conduct and behavior of bus drivers, cleanliness and upkeep of buses, customer service, are most expediently dealt with by the bus operator directly. These operational matters also include the upkeep of facilities at bus interchanges, positioning and placement of bus service signboards and the display of service information at bus stops.

topics.title: Matters Commonly Misdirected to the PTC

questionListItems.title: Shouldn't fare adjustment take into account service level?

answer.body:
The issue of service quality is kept separate from the fare formula. This allows the fare review mechanism to truly reflect and address the cost changes of the operators without making the fare formula too complicated.

Commuters' interest in terms of service provision will continue to be safeguarded by existing regulatory framework for bus and train services.

questionListItems.title: The taxi driver intentionally took a longer way to my destination and even shouted at me when I tried to correct him. What can I do?

answer.body:
Taxi operators are directly responsible for the satisfactory delivery of services such as customer service, conduct of drivers, etc.

For taxi-related matter, you may approach the respective taxi operators directly, or the LTA, the licensing authority of taxi services and taxi drivers in Singapore. The PTC has no jurisdiction over such matters.

topics.title: Matters Commonly Misdirected to the PTC

answer.body: Distance Fares were introduced in 2010 to bring about a more integrated fare structure that allows commuters to make transfers without incurring additional cost, thus offering greater choice and flexibility in how they plan their journey. Under Distance Fares, commuters travelling the same distance will pay the same fare for the same type of service, whether they travel direct or make transfers.

questionListItems.title: What can a driver do if he/she is in danger of being assaulted by a fare evader, or when a fare evader flees from the taxi/PHC?

answer.body:
For their own safety, drivers are advised not to pursue the fare evader. Instead, the driver should lodge a non-payment of fare report with his/her operator.

If drivers perceive an immediate risk to their safety:

  • Taxi drivers can activate the panic button installed in the taxi to alert the taxi company's call centre. The taxi company's call centre will be able to identify the location of the taxi through the GPS system, and alert other taxi drivers in the vicinity and police if further assistance is required.

  • PHC drivers can activate the emergency call feature on their ride-hail operator's mobile application or call the police directly for assistance.

topics.title: Fare Evasion and Overcharging for Point-to-Point Services

questionListItems.title: What is the penalty for fare evasion?

answer.body: Under the Public Transport Council Act, a person who is convicted for the offence of evading street-hail or ride-hail fare is liable to a fine not exceeding $1,000. A repeat offender is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $2,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or both.

topics.title: Fare Evasion and Overcharging for Point-to-Point Services

questionListItems.title: What is the purpose of the penalty fee system?

answer.body: The purpose of the penalty fee regime is to deter fare evasion. Collective instances and rise in fare evasion can translate into fare increase if left unchecked. It is thus imperative to curb fare evasion, thereby reducing fare leakage which in turn helps to safeguard the interests of the majority of passengers who pay the correct fares.

questionListItems.title: What types of overcharging can PTC enforce against under the new framework? How will PTC enforce against overcharging by P2P drivers?

answer.body: PTC will work with LTA to investigate complaints of overcharging by drivers and statutory action will be taken against the offenders if investigations find them to be liable.

topics.title: Fare Evasion and Overcharging for Point-to-Point Services

questionListItems.title: When was the Penalty Fee Regime Implemented?

answer.body: The Penalty Fee Regime was implemented on 1 July 2008.

questionListItems.title: Which station pairs can commuters make their walking transfers to benefit from the Enhanced Transfer Rules?

answer.body:
Station pairs in close proximity include:

  • Bras Basah > Bencoolen

  • City Hall > Esplanade

  • Bencoolen > Dhoby Ghaut

  • Rochor > Jalan Besar

  • Downtown > Marina Bay

  • Raffles Place > Telok Ayer

questionListItems.title: Why are commuters targeted for underpaying while operators get away with incidents of overcharging/incorrect fare deductions?

answer.body:
The objective of the penalty fee system is to deter passengers from evading fares and therefore reduce fare leakage which in turn helps to safeguard the interests of the majority of passengers who pay the correct fares. The ticketing system is designed and developed by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) in collaboration with the public transport operators (PTOs).

 

We understand that the LTA and PTOs strive to keep system error low. In instances of over-charging, the PTOs have to provide refunds for valid claims for over-charging.

 

For clarification on the ticketing system, commuters may submit your feedback online via https://www.lta.gov.sg/feedback. For filing of claims, commuters can do so via the SimplyGo app or website (www.simplygo.com.sg), contact the SimplyGo Hotline at 1800-2255 663, or visit the nearest SimplyGo Ticket Office or SimplyGo Kiosk.

questionListItems.title: Why are the Enhanced Transfer Rules not applicable at Bukit Panjang, Newton and Tampines MRT stations?

answer.body:
The new transfer rules are for transfers between different stations, not within an interchange station. Therefore, these rules will not apply to Bukit Panjang, Newton and Tampines MRT stations as these are designated as interchange stations.

Commuters who change lines at these interchange stations will not be considered as having made a transfer. They will be charged based on the shortest travel paths between their origin and destination stations, without incurring any additional boarding charges.

questionListItems.title: Why are the lower morning pre-peak fares not applicable for bus journeys?

answer.body:
Lower morning pre-peak fares are meant to encourage rail commuters to travel outside morning peak hours, when travel demand is the heaviest. Peak period crowding on buses is not as acute.

In fact, with 1,000 buses added under the Bus Service Enhancement Programme and bus service standards improving as part of the transition to bus contracting, many bus services have become less crowded even as ridership continued increasing.
